November 21 – Large-scale Bleeding Kansas violence begins, with events leading to the 'Wakarusa War' between antislavery and proslavery forces.

November 15 – The Hejaz rebellion takes place in Hejaz against the Ottoman Empire, triggered by a firman of against the slave trade, which is condemned by the ulema of Mecca as influenced by Westerners and contrary to Islamic law.
Mauveine, the first synthetic organic dye, is discovered by William Henry Perkin, while attempting to synthesize quinine. This eventually leads to the birth of the chemical industry.
April – The Xhosa cattle-killing movement and famine begins in Cape Colony.
The Tintic War breaks out in Utah.
Kate Warne, the first female private detective, begins to work for the Pinkerton Detective Agency.
January 23 – The American sidewheel steamer SS Pacific leaves Liverpool for a transatlantic voyage on which she will be lost with all 186 on board.
December – The Reform War in Mexico begins.
March 12 – Elizabeth Blackwell opens a hospital, the New York Infirmary for Indigent Women and Children.
December 20 – Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria issues a decree, Es ist Mein Wille, which leads to the demolition of the city walls of Vienna, allowing the construction of the Ringstraße.
November 16 – Indian Rebellion of : British troops win 24 Victoria Crosses in action this day.
San Jose State, the first public U.S. university west of the Mississippi River, opens in San Francisco as Minn's Evening School.

The Government of India Act, passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, transfers the territories of the British East India Company and their administration to the direct rule of the British Crown, through a Secretary of State for India.
A bill is passed to create a modern sewage system in London as a result of the Great Stink, when the heat of the summer made the smell from sewage in the Thames unbearable.
June 13–17 – The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending the first part of the Second Opium War.
March 21 – Indian Rebellion: British troops retake Lucknow.
October 21 – Jacques Offenbach's operetta Orpheus in the Underworld, featuring music associated with the can-can, is first performed in Paris.
June 30 – Charles Blondin crosses Niagara Falls on a tightrope for the first time.
Count Camillo Benso di Cavour resigns, as president of Piedmont-Sardinia.
The University of Michigan Law School is founded.
District nursing begins in Liverpool, England, when philanthropist William Rathbone employs Mary Robinson to nurse the sick poor in their own homes.
The so-called Pig War border dispute between the Americans and the British, over the San Juan Islands, begins by the death of the namesake pig.
In Buenos Aires, leader Bartolomé Mitre subverts the Argentine Confederation and begins to establish a new centralist government, with the help of Uruguayan Colorado party leader Venancio Flores.
October 6 – Section 377 of the British Indian penal code was enacted in British India.

October 5 – Austria, Britain, France, Prussia and the Ottoman Empire form a commission to investigate the causes of the massacres of Maronite Christians, committed by Druzes in Lebanon earlier in the year.
Meeting at Teano: Giuseppe Garibaldi gives Naples to King Victor Emmanuel II, recognizing him as King of Italy.
Napoleon III, Emperor of the French, and Empress Eugénie visit Algiers and stay at the Casbah of Algiers.
May 31 – The Perpetual Truce of Peace and Friendship is signed between Bahrain and the United Kingdom.
March 28 – Confederate Arizona: A convention in modern-day Tucson ratifies the ordinance of secession of the southern part of New Mexico Territory.
March 11 – American Civil War: The Constitution of the Confederate States of America is adopted.
October 26 – The Pony Express American transcontinental mail service announces its closure.

March 20
Unification of Italy: The surrender of Civitella del Tronto ends the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies. An earthquake completely destroys Mendoza, Argentina.
Notts County F.C. is founded in Nottingham, England, making it (by the ) the world's oldest professional Association football team.
January 1 – The United Kingdom annexes Lagos Island, in modern-day Nigeria.
American Civil War: President Abraham Lincoln removes George B. McClellan as commander of the Union Army.
April 25 – Capture of New Orleans – Forces under Union Admiral David Farragut occupy the Confederate city of New Orleans, securing access to the Mississippi River.
August 28–30 – Second Battle of Bull Run – Confederate forces inflict a crushing defeat on Union General John Pope.
November 19 – U.S. President Abraham Lincoln delivers the Gettysburg Address, at the military cemetery dedication ceremony in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.

November 25 – Battle of Missionary Ridge – At Missionary Ridge in Tennessee, Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant break the siege of Chattanooga, by routing Confederate troops under General Braxton Bragg.
November 15 – King Christian IX of Denmark succeeds his distant cousin Frederick VII, giving rise to the beginning of the Second Schleswig-Holstein crisis.

June 13 – Samuel Butler's dystopian article "Darwin among the Machines" is published (under the pen name Cellarius) in The Press newspaper in Christchurch, New Zealand; it will be incorporated into his novel Erewhon.
October 14 – Battle of Bristoe Station – Confederate General Robert E. Lee's forces fail to drive the Union army out of Virginia.

American Civil War:
November 15 – Sherman's March to the Sea begins: Union General Sherman burns Atlanta and starts to move south, living off the land, and causing extensive devastation to crops and mills. November 20 – The judicial reform of Alexander II is launched in the Russian Empire.
Battle of Brice's Crossroads – Confederate troops under Nathan Bedford Forrest defeat a much larger Union force, led by General Samuel D. Sturgis, in Mississippi.
June 27 – American Civil War: Battle of Kennesaw Mountain – Confederate troops defeat Union forces near Kennesaw, Georgia.
James Clerk Maxwell presents his paper, A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic Field, to the Royal Society in London, treating light as an electromagnetic wave.
May 21 – The Russian Empire begins the Circassian genocide. More than 1.5 million Circassians are driven from their homeland to the Ottoman Empire, ending the Russo-Circassian War.
June 26 – Jumbo, a young male African elephant, arrives at London Zoo and becomes a popular attraction.
In North Bend, Ohio (a suburb of Cincinnati), the first train robbery in the country takes place.
June 10 – Richard Wagner's opera Tristan und Isolde debuts at the Munich Court Theatre.
French missionary Father Armand David first observes Père David's deer in Peking, China.
February 21 – John Deere receives a United States patent for ploughs.
June 14 – The Austro-Prussian War ("Seven Weeks War") begins when the Austrians and most of the medium-size German states declare war on Prussia.
July 28 – The Metric Act of becomes law and legalizes the standardization of weights and measures in the United States.
The last issue of the abolitionist magazine The Liberator is published.
Federalist revolts occur in Argentina.
May 1–3 – The Memphis massacre: a rebellion with a series of violent racial events.

March 29 – The British North America Act receives royal assent, forming the Dominion of Canada, in an event known as the Confederation. This unites the Province of Canada (Quebec and Ontario), New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia on July 1.
Canadian Confederation: Queen Victoria signs the British North America Act, creating the Dominion of Canada, effective July 1.
Pierre Michaux invents the front wheel-driven velocipede, the first mass-produced bicycle.

May 29
The Austro-Hungarian Compromise (called Ausgleich in German or kiegyezés in Hungarian (The Compromise)) is born through Act 12, which establishes the Austro-Hungarian Empire; on June 8 Emperor Francis Joseph of Austria is crowned King of Hungary. Canadian Confederation: Queen Victoria signs the British North America Act, creating the Dominion of Canada, effective July 1.
March 5 – The Fenian Rising breaks out in Ireland.
The Dortmunder Actien Brauerei is founded in Germany.
May 10–14 – Boshin War – Battle of Utsunomiya Castle, Japan: Forces of the Emperor Meiji resist the retreating troops of the Tokugawa shogunate.
March 24 – The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is formed, in New York City.
May 30 – Memorial Day is observed in the United States for the first time (it was proclaimed on May 5 by General John A. Logan).

April 9–13 – Battle of Magdala: A British-Indian task force under Robert Napier inflicts 700 deaths and a crushing defeat on the army of Emperor Tewodros II; the British and Indians suffer 30 wounded, two of whom subsequently die. Tewodros commits suicide and Magdala is captured, ending the British Expedition to Abyssinia.
The Red River Rebellion breaks out against British forces in Canada.

November 6 – The first game of American football between two American colleges is played. Rutgers University defeats Princeton University 6–4, in a forerunner to American football and College football.
Friedrich Miescher purifies nuclein, which was then identified as deoxyribonucleic acid.
April 6 – The American Museum of Natural History is founded in New York.

December 10
Women's suffrage: The Wyoming territorial legislature gives women the right to vote, the first such law in the world. The first American chapter of Kappa Sigma is founded at the University of Virginia.
February 14 – Schoolteacher Seraph Young Ford was the first woman to vote under a women’s equal suffrage law in the USA, casting her ballot in the Salt Lake City municipal election.
January 3 – Construction of the Brooklyn Bridge begins in New York City.
June 8 – The final splice on the first telegraph submarine cable between Great Britain and India is made.

May 12
The Canadian province of Manitoba is created, in response to Louis Riel's Red River Rebellion. The Port Adelaide Football Club is founded.
A 6.6 earthquake shakes the Canadian province of Quebec, killing 6 people.

July 20
British Columbia joins the confederation of Canada. C.
June 27 – The Meiji government officially adopts the yen as Japan's modern unit of currency. Coins which have been made in advance with the date are released into circulation.

March 18 – Origin of the Paris Commune: Troops of the regular French Army, sent by Adolphe Thiers, Chef du pouvoir executive de la République française, to seize cannons stored on the hill of Montmartre, fraternise with civilians and the National Guard, and two army generals are killed. Regular troops are evacuated to Versailles.
Modern "neoclassical economics" is initiated by publication of William Stanley Jevons's Theory of Political Economy and Carl Menger's Principles of Economics (Grundsätze der Volkswirtschaftslehre).
May 4 – The first supposedly Major League Baseball game is played in America.

November 9 – Great Boston Fire of : In Boston, Massachusetts, a large fire begins to burn on Lincoln Street (the 2-day disaster destroys about 65 acres (0.26 km) of the city, 776 buildings, much of the financial district and causes US$60 million in damage).

December 1
Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada becomes constitutional President of Mexico. Responsible government is granted to Cape Colony (South Africa).
Horace Greeley, President Ulysses S. Grant's opponent in this year's U.S. presidential election, dies.
Tsukuba University is founded in Japan, as a teacher training college.
Kimberly, Clark and Co. is founded in Neenah, Wisconsin, by John A. Kimberly, Charles B.
October 29 – At Dresden, Albrecht I becomes new King Albrecht I of King of Saxony, an independent state within the German Empire, upon the death of his father King Johann, who had ruled since.

May 9
Der Gründerkrach: The Wiener Börse (Vienna stock exchange) crash in Austria-Hungary ends the Gründerzeit, and heralds the global Panic of and Long Depression. Third Carlist War: The Battle of Montejurra is fought at Navarra, Spain.
Japan adopts the Gregorian calendar.
The Swedish arms company Aktiebolaget Bofors-Gullspång, better known as Bofors, is founded.
British naval officer John Moresby discovers the site of Port Moresby in Papua New Guinea, and claims the land for Britain.
Mathew Evans and Henry Woodward patent the first incandescent lamp, with an electric light bulb.
November 25 – The United States Greenback Party is established as a political party, made primarily of farmers financially hurt by the Panic of.
The Dresden English Football Club is founded, the first association football club on the European mainland.
November 16 – Premiere of Alfred Cellier's comic opera The Sultan of Mocha at the Prince's Theatre, Manchester.
Charles Taze Russell and the Bible Student movement claim this year marks the invisible return of Jesus Christ to earth.

March 3
Bizet's Carmen is first performed at the Opéra-Comique, Paris, France, three months before the composer's death. The Page Act of is enacted in the United States, effectively prohibiting the immigration of Chinese women.
April 10 – The Arya Samaj is founded in Mumbai by Swami Dayananda Saraswati.
January 12 – Guangxu becomes the 11th Qing dynasty Emperor of China at the age of 3. He succeeds his cousin, the Tongzhi Emperor, who had no sons of his own.
June 4 – Two American colleges play each other in arguably the first game of college football: Tufts University and Harvard University at Jarvis Field in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
August 6 – Hibernian F.C. is founded by Irishmen in Edinburgh, Scotland.

February 28 – Third Carlist War: The Carlist forces do not succeed, and the promises are never fulfilled. The Carlist pretender Carlos, Duke of Madrid, goes into exile in France, bringing the conflict to an end after four years.
September 26 – Global consumer goods and personal care company Henkel is founded by Friedrich Karl Henkel in Aachen, Germany.
United States presidential election: After long and heated disputes, Rutherford B. Hayes is eventually declared the winner over Samuel J.
Construction of Spandau Prison in Berlin is completed.

April 1 – Lars Magnus Ericsson starts a small mechanical workshop in Stockholm, Sweden (from April 27 partnering with Carl Johan Andersson), dealing with telegraphy equipment, which grows into the worldwide company Ericsson.
August 18 – Asaph Hall discovers Phobos, the inner moon of Mars.
Russo-Turkish War: The second battle in the siege of Plevna is fought.
April 24 – Russo-Turkish War (–): Russia declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
The University of Tokyo is officially established in Japan.
May 9 – Iquique Earthquake and tsunami: An earthquake of at least magnitude 8.5 Ms occurs on the west coast of South America, killing 2,541 around the Pacific Rim.

March 3 (February 19 O.S.) – Treaty of San Stefano signed between the Russian and Ottoman Empires following Russian victory in the Russo-Turkish War (–) provides for establishment of an autonomous Principality of Bulgaria (although not as large as originally envisaged). Russia however regards the treaty as a preliminary one only, refusing on March 25 a British proposal to lay it before a European congress, and matters are finally settled in July's Treaty of Berlin.
July 4 – A match race between champion thoroughbred racehorses Ten Broeck and Mollie McCarty draws more than 30,000 fans to Louisville, and inspires the folk song, "Molly and Tenbrooks".
November 17 – The first assassination attempt is made against Umberto I of Italy by anarchist Giovanni Passannante, armed with a dagger. The King survives with a slight wound in one arm.
October 27 – The Manhattan Savings Institution robbery occurs.
October 31 – A fire destroys the Eldkvarn gristmill in Stockholm, Sweden.
September 23 – The Macedo-Romanian Cultural Society is founded.

December 31
Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey. Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera The Pirates of Penzance opens at the Fifth Avenue Theatre in New York City (following a token performance the day before for U.K. copyright reasons in Paignton, Devon).
December 2-28 – the Winter cold wave freeze Europe with record low temperatures.
June 4 – Yasukuni Shrine is officially renamed from Tokyo Shokonsha Shrine in Japan.
February 3 – Mosley Street in Newcastle upon Tyne becomes the world's first public highway to be lit by the electric incandescent light bulb invented by Joseph Swan.
November 22 – Vaudeville actress Lillian Russell makes her debut at Tony Pastor's Theatre, in New York City.
July 14 – Dorchester Penitentiary opens in Canada.
The Capuchin catacombs of Palermo are officially closed (there will be some burials afterwards).
November 4 – The first cash register is patented by James and John Ritty of Dayton, Ohio.

February 24 – The SS Columbia, which will be the first outside usage of Thomas Edison's incandescent light bulb, is launched at the Delaware River Iron Ship Building and Engine Works of John Roach & Sons in Chester, Pennsylvania.
August 3 – The Pretoria Convention peace treaty is signed, officially ending the war between the Boers and Britain.
April 25 – Caulfield Grammar School is founded in Melbourne, Australia.
February 18 – Carlos Finlay introduces his discovery of the transmission of Yellow Fever by mosquitoes Aedes aegypti, in the Fifth International Sanitary Conference held in Washington, D.C.
September 26 – Godalming becomes the first town in England to have its streets illuminated by electric light (hydroelectrically generated).

April 15
Temuco, Chile, is founded. Anti-Semitic pogroms in Southern Russia begin.
March 2 – Roderick Maclean fails in an attempt to assassinate Queen Victoria, at Windsor.
August 20 – Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's Overture debuts in Moscow.
The first United States Labor Day parade is held in New York City.

May 2 – The Kilmainham Treaty, an agreement between the British government and Irish nationalist leader Charles Stewart Parnell to abate tenant rent arrears, is announced; Parnell is released from Kilmainham Gaol in Dublin.
July 31 – The Hebrew Moshava of Rishon LeZion in Palestine is founded.
October 24 – Cardiff University, Wales, opens (under the name of University College of South Wales and Monmouthshire).
March 28 – Battle of Gia Cuc: A French force defeats the Vietnamese in northern Vietnam in the run-up to the Sino-French War.
American Old West: Self-described Black Bart the Po-8 makes his last stagecoach robbery, but leaves a handkerchief with a laundry mark that eventually leads to his capture.
Houghton College in New York State.
The AH begins in the Islamic calendar on the 1st of Muharram, 1301 AH.
The Stefan–Boltzmann law is reformulated by Ludwig Boltzmann.
February 1 – A New English Dictionary on historical principles, part 1 (edited by James A. H.
December 9 – Tom Dudley and Edwin Stephens are convicted of murder in the survival cannibalism case of R v. Dudley and Stephens in the English courts.
The International Meridian Conference meeting in Washington, D.C., fixes the Greenwich meridian as the world's prime meridian (voted on October 13).
March – John Joseph Montgomery conducts the first manned glider flights in the United States near Otay, California.
The Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association is established in the United Kingdom, to provide charitable assistance.
April 2 – Frog Lake Massacre: Cree warriors led by Wandering Spirit kill 9 settlers at Frog Lake in the Northwest Territories.
August 29 – Gottlieb Daimler is granted a German patent for the Daimler Reitwagen, regarded as the first motorcycle, which he has produced with Wilhelm Maybach.
John Kemp Starley demonstrates the Rover safety bicycle in Coventry, regarded as the first practical modern bicycle.
Camp Dudley, the oldest continually running boys' camp in the United States, is founded.
May 15 – Portugal and France agree to regulate the borders of their colonies in Guinea.
September 4 – American Indian Wars: After almost 30 years of fighting, Apache leader Geronimo surrenders, with his last band of warriors, to General Nelson Miles, at Skeleton Canyon in Arizona.
January 29 – Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile, the Benz Patent-Motorwagen (built in ).
Addis Ababa is founded in the Ethiopian Empire.
May 17 – Motherwell Football Club is founded in Scotland.
September 5 – The Theatre Royal, Exeter, England, burns down, killing 186 people.
Construction work begins on the foundations of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.
March 3 – Anne Sullivan begins teaching Helen Keller. March 3: Helen Keller and Sullivan.
February 4 – The Interstate Commerce Act of, passed by the 49th United States Congress, is signed into law by President Grover Cleveland.

July 6
King Kalākaua of Hawai'i is forced by anti-monarchists to sign the 'Bayonet Constitution', stripping the Hawaiian monarchy of much of its authority, as well as disenfranchising most native Hawaiians, all Asians and the poor. Berthe bombing, targetting a Parisian landowner in conflict with several Italian anarchists.
John Robert Gregg first publishes Gregg shorthand in the United States.
American writer Ernest Thayer's baseball poem "Casey at the Bat" is first published (under the pen name "Phin") as the last of his humorous contributions to The San Francisco Examiner.

Battle of Guté Dili: Seeking to extend Mahdist control over what is becomes southwestern Ethiopia, governor Khalil al-Khuzani is routed by an alliance of Shewan forces, under Ras Gobana Dacche and Moroda Bekere, ruler of Leqa Naqamte. Only a handful, including Khalil, barely manage to flee the battlefield.
In England, the first six Football League matches are played.
The dolphin Pelorus Jack is first sighted in Cook Strait, New Zealand.

The last official bare-knuckle boxing title fight is held (under London Prize Ring Rules): Heavyweight Champion John L. Sullivan, the Boston Strong Boy, defeats Jake Kilrain in a world championship bout, lasting 75 rounds, in Mississippi.
Gustav Mahler premieres his Symphony No. 1, in Budapest.
June 6 – The Great Seattle Fire ravages through the downtown area without any fatalities.
March 12 – Almon B. Strowger, an undertaker in Topeka, Kansas, files a patent in the United States for an automatic telephone exchange using the Strowger switch.
November 19 – The modern-day flag of Brazil is adopted by the Provisional Government of the Republic.
November 4 – The first deep level London Underground Railway, the City and South London Railway, opens officially.
October 11 – In Washington, D.C., the Daughters of the American Revolution is founded.
July 13 – In Minnesota, storms result in the Sea Wing disaster on Lake Pepin, killing 98.
The folding carton box is invented by Robert Gair, a Brooklyn printer who developed production of paper-board boxes in.
September 19 – The University of North Texas is founded, as the Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute.
January 15 – Scottish railway strikers attempt to wreck a train near Greenock, Scotland.
James Naismith invents basketball in the United States.
June 15 – Minas Gerais was granted in.
A fight between railway strikers and police breaks out at Motherwell, Scotland.
May 15 – Pope Leo XIII issues the encyclical Rerum novarum, on the rights and duties of capital and labor, resulting in the creation of many Christian Democrat parties throughout Europe.
July 8 – The Great Fire of devastates the city of St. John's, Newfoundland.
Dr. José Rizal, Filipino writer, philosopher and political activist, is arrested by Spanish authorities in connection with La Liga Filipina.
October 31 – The first collection of Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes stories from The Strand Magazine, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes, is published in London.
November 17 – French troops occupy Abomey, capital of the kingdom of Dahomey.
May 22 – The British conquest of Ijebu Ode marks a major extension of colonial power into the Nigerian interior.
Genoa Cricket & Athletic Club, the oldest Italian Association football club, is formed.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom has its first meeting.
The Wengernalpbahn railway in Wengen, Switzerland (Canton of Bern) is opened.
Russian monitor Rusalka sinks in a storm in the Gulf of Finland, with the loss of all 177 crew; her hulk is eventually discovered in 2003 off Helsinki.
January 2 – Webb C. Ball introduces railroad chronometers, which become the general railroad timepiece standards in North America.
Spillers Records is founded in Cardiff, the world's oldest record shop still in operation.

November 21 – First Sino-Japanese War: Battle of Lushunkou – Japanese troops secure a decisive victory over the Chinese, capture the port city of Lüshunkou, and begin the Port Arthur massacre, in which more than 1,000 Chinese servicemen and civilians die.
November 6 – Republicans win by a landslide in the United States House of Representatives elections, which sets the stage for the decisive presidential election of.

March 5 – The Local Government Act (coming into effect December –January ) reforms local government in Britain, creating a system of urban and rural districts with elected councils, with elected civil parish councils in rural areas, and gives women, irrespective of marital status, the right to vote and stand in local (but not national) elections.
The football club FC La Chaux-de-Fonds is founded in Switzerland.
The world's first portable handheld electric drill is developed, by brothers Wilhelm and Carl Fein in Germany.
January 24 – An effort to restore the Hawaiian monarchy ends as the former Queen Liliʻuokalani abdicates and pledges allegiance to the Republic of Hawaii.
March 30 – Rudolf Diesel patents the Diesel engine in Germany.
December 28 – Auguste and Louis Lumière make what is probably the first commercial public screening of projected moving picture films to a paying audience, at the Salon Indien du Grand Café in Paris.
March 18 – The world's first gasoline bus route is started in Germany, between Siegen and Netphen.
April 9 – The National Farm School (later Delaware Valley College) is chartered in Doylestown, Pennsylvania.
The pharmaceutical and healthcare company Hoffmann-La Roche in Switzerland comes wholly under the control of Fritz Hoffmann-La Roche.
December 30 – José Rizal, Filipino scholar and poet, is executed by Spanish authorities in the Philippines.
January 2 – The Jameson Raid comes to an end as Jameson surrenders to the Boers.
May 13 – The Franchise Bill is passed by the Colony of Natal's Legislative Assembly, disfranchising natives of other countries.

April 15
Drillers near Bartlesville, Oklahoma strike oil for the first time, in the designated "Indian Territory", on land leased from the Osage Indians. The gusher, at the Nellie Johnstone Number One well, leads to rapid population growth.
December 30 – Natal annexes Zululand.
May 22 – The Blackwall Tunnel, at this time the longest underwater road tunnel in the world, is opened for traffic beneath the River Thames in the East End of London by the Prince of Wales.
January 7 – A cyclone destroys Darwin, Australia.

August 10 – At the Bayer pharmaceutical company, pharmacist Felix Hoffmann successfully synthesizes acetylsalicylic acid, after isolating a compound from a plant of the Spiraea family; the company markets it under the brand name "Aspirin".
June 10 – Tuone Udaina, the last known speaker of the Dalmatian language, is killed in an explosion.

The Wilmington insurrection of begins as a coup d'état by the white Democratic Party of the U.S. state of North Carolina against the Republican Mayor of Wilmington. On the first day, a building housing a negro newspaper is burned and eight African Americans are killed.
May 7–9 – Bava Beccaris massacre: Hundreds of demonstrators are killed, when General Fiorenzo Bava Beccaris orders troops to fire on a rally in Milan, Italy.
November 11 – In Wilmington, negro leaders and white republicans are forced to leave the city by new government.
Bartolomé Masó, the President of the República de Cuba en Armas that had been founded during the Cuban War of Independence, resigns.

August 20 – The Kiram–Bates Treaty is signed in the Philippines, with U.S. forces recognizing the autonomy of local governments in the Sulu Archipelago (within the Mindanao island group) in return for the Sultan's assistance in suppressing attacks on U.S. forces.
January 3 – A treaty of alliance is signed between Russia and Afghanistan.

January 5 –
A fierce battle is fought between American troops and Filipino defenders at the town of Pililla on the island of Luzon.
In the Battle of Togbao in Chad, the French Bretonnet–Braun mission is destroyed by the warlord Rabih az-Zubayr.

Dreyfus affair: France's Court of Cassation orders a reopening of the conviction for treason of French Army Captain Alfred Dreyfus after evidence of a wrongful conviction is made public, and directs that Dreyfus be returned to France after five years of imprisonment on Devil's Island.
June 5 – Second Boer War: British soldiers take Pretoria.
Second Boer War: British military leaders accept the unconditional notice of surrender from Boer General Piet Cronjé.
September 8 – The Galveston hurricane, killing around 8,000 people. It is the deadliest hurricane in U.S. history.
March 5 – Two U.S. Navy cruisers are sent to Central America to protect American interests in a dispute between Nicaragua and Costa Rica.
January 27 – Boxer Rebellion: Foreign diplomats in Peking, Qing dynasty China, demand that the Boxer rebels (who oppose foreign interests in the country) be disciplined.
C. : Senwosret II (Twelfth Dynasty) started to rule. He built Kahun near his pyramid tomb complex at el-Lahun.
C. : Port of Lothal is abandoned.
- : Head of Senusret III is made. Twelfth dynasty of Egypt.
C. : Pharaoh Senwosret III starts to rule (other date is ).
C. : Pharaoh Senwosret II starts to rule (other date is ).
Leon Czolgosz is executed in the electric chair for the assassination of William McKinley in Buffalo, New York on September 6.

July 4
The 1,282 foot (390 m) covered bridge crossing the Saint John River at Hartland, New Brunswick, Canada opens. It is the longest covered bridge in the world.
March 5 – Irish nationalist demonstrators are ejected by police from the House of Commons of the United Kingdom in London.
June 18 – British peace campaigner Emily Hobhouse reports on the high mortality and cruel conditions in the Second Boer War concentration camps.
August 21 – The International Secretariat of National Trade Union Centres is founded in Copenhagen.
April 11 – Tenor Enrico Caruso makes the first million-selling recording, for the Gramophone Company in Milan.

December 17 – The Commercial Telegraph Agency (TTA, Torgovo-Telegrafnue Agenstvo), predecessor of TASS, is officially established under the Ministry of Finance at Saint Petersburg in the Russian Empire.
April 19 – The 7.5 Mw Guatemala earthquake shakes Guatemala with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII, killing between 800 and 2,000.
The capital of French Indochina is moved from Saigon (in Cochinchina) to Hanoi.
King Leopold II of Belgium survives an attempted assassination in Brussels by Italian anarchist Gennaro Rubino.

April 19–21 (April 6–8 O.S.) – The first Kishinev pogrom, beginning on Easter Day, takes place in Kishinev, capital of the Bessarabia Governorate of the Russian Empire. At least 47 Jews are killed during mob rioting encouraged by blood libel articles in the press and led by priests.
August 2 – The Ilinden–Preobrazhenie Uprising, organized by the Secret Macedonian-Adrianople Revolutionary Organization, breaks out in the Ottoman provinces of Macedonia and Adrianople.
March 12 – The University of Puerto Rico is founded.

December 17 – Orville Wright flies an aircraft with a petrol engine, the Wright Flyer, at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina in the first documented and successful powered and controlled heavier-than-air flight.
November 6 – The English-language South China Morning Post newspaper is first published in Hong Kong.
May 21 – The International Federation of Association Football, FIFA, is established.
October 19 – Polytechnic University of the Philippines is founded as Manila Business School, through the superintendence of American C. A.
Global cosmetics companies are founded in Paris : Coty, by François Coty, and Garnier, by Alfred Amour Garnier.
January 12 – The Herero Wars in German South West Africa begin.
August 3 – British expedition to Tibet: The British expedition under Colonel Francis Younghusband takes Lhasa, Tibet.
Yen Chia-kan, 2nd President of the Republic of China (d. ).
Chau Sen Cocsal Chhum, Cambodian politician, prime minister (d. 2009).
Eleanor Audley, American actress (d. ).
September 8 – The 7.2 Mw Calabria earthquake shakes Southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI, killing between 557 and 2,500 people.
June 25 – The Danish Navy training ship Georg Stage is accidentally sunk in port in Copenhagen after English steamship Ancona collides with it, killing 22 teenage recruits.
The Simplo Filler Pen Company is founded, later to become the Montblanc Company in Germany.
September 30 – The first Gordon Bennett Cup in ballooning is held, starting in Paris. The winning team, piloting the balloon United States, lands in Fylingdales, Yorkshire, England.
Construction begins on the modern-day Great Mosque of Djenné.

October 11 – A United States diplomatic crisis with Japan arises when the San Francisco public school board orders Japanese students to be taught in racially segregated schools (it is resolved by next year).
June 26 – The first autombile racing Grand Prix is the French Grand Prix held at Le Mans.
James M. Spangler invents the first Hoover vacuum cleaner.
October 27 – Černová massacre: Fifteen people are shot during the consecration of a Catholic church in Hungary (modern-day Slovakia).
March 25 – The first university sports federation in Europe is established in Hungary, with the participation or support of the associations of ten universities and colleges.
July 24 – The Japan–Korea Treaty of brings the government and military of the protectorate of Korea more firmly under Japanese control.

March
The steamship Congo collides at the mouth of the Ems River with the German steamship Nerissa; 7 lives are lost. The Romanian Peasants' Revolt results in possibly as many as 11,000 deaths.
September 17 – At Fort Myer, Virginia, Thomas Selfridge becomes the first person to die in an airplane crash. The pilot, Orville Wright, is severely injured in the crash but recovers.
May 14–October 31 – The Franco-British Exhibition is held in London.
August 17 – “Fantasmagorie”, an animated short film by Émile Cohl, which is widely regarded as the first animated cartoon is officially released.
January 24 – Robert Baden-Powell's Scouting for Boys begins publication in London. The book eventually sells over 100 million copies, and effectively begins the worldwide Boy Scout movement.
December 2 – Emperor Puyi ascends the Chinese throne at age 2.

December 14 – New South Wales Premier Charles Wade signs the Seat of Government Surrender Act, formally completing the transfer of State land to the Commonwealth, to create the Australian Capital Territory.
April 11 – The city of Tel Aviv (known in its first year as Ahuzat Bayit) is founded by the Jewish community, on the outskirts of Jaffa (at this time in the Ottoman Empire).
April 14 – Adana massacre: Ottoman Turks kill 15,000–30,000 Armenian Christians, in the Adana Vilayet.
March 31 – Construction begins on the RMS Titanic, at the Harland and Wolff Shipyard in Belfast.
October 16 – The Pittsburgh Pirates defeat the Detroit Tigers to win the World Series.
June 22 – DELAG Zeppelin dirigible Deutschland makes the first commercial passenger flight, from Friedrichshafen to Düsseldorf in Germany; the flight takes 9 hours.
The Philadelphia Athletics defeat the Chicago Cubs, 7–2, to win the World Series in baseball in Game 5 (Jack Coombs has been the winning pitcher in three of the Athletics' four wins).
August 22 – The Japan–Korea Treaty of, by which the Empire of Japan formally annexes the Korean Empire, is signed (it becomes effectively void in, which is formally recognised in ).
April 5 – The Transandine Railway connecting Chile and Argentina is inaugurated.
Infrared photographs are first published by Professor Robert Williams Wood, in the Royal Photographic Society's journal.
December 12 – The Delhi Durbar is held to mark the coronation of George V and Queen Mary as Emperor and Empress of India, and the transfer of the capital of British India from Calcutta to Delhi.
May 17 – Mexican Revolution: Porfirio Díaz is convinced to resign, but does not do so yet.
August 21 – Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa is stolen from the Louvre museum in Paris by Vincenzo Peruggia; the painting is returned in.
September 25 – French battleship Liberté explodes at anchor in Toulon, France, killing around 300 onboard and in the surrounding area.

June 21 – RMS Olympic arrives in New York at the end of her maiden voyage. She proceeds to her quarantine station off Staten Island, which she leaves at 7:45 a.m., and is saluted on her way up New York Harbor by all kinds of craft as she steams to Pier 59 in the North River.
December 24 – Merck files patent applications in Germany for synthesis of the entactogenic drug MDMA, developed by Anton Köllisch.
April 16 – Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly across the English Channel.
June 6 – The Novarupta volcano is formed in Alaska by a VEI 6 eruption, the world's largest (in terms of matter emitted) in the.
August 21 – The first Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America) earns his rank.
October 16 – Bulgarian pilots Radul Minkov and Prodan Toprakchiev perform the second bombing with an airplane in history, at the railway station of Karaagac near Edirne, against Turkey.
October 1 – Mexican Revolution: Pancho Villa's troops take Torreón after a 3-day battle, when government troops retreat.
November 7–11 – The Great Lakes Storm of in North America claims 19 ships, and more than 250 lives.
December 24 – Italian Hall disaster: seventy-three people – mostly striking mine workers and their families – are crushed to death in a stampede in Calumet, Michigan.
June 24 – Joseph Cook becomes the 6th Prime Minister of Australia.
Buenos Aires Underground, the first in South America, opens.

September 30
World War I: British Indian Army Expeditionary Force A arrives at Marseille for service in the Ypres Salient of the Western Front. The Flying Squadron of America is established to promote the temperance movement.

September 13 – World War I:
The conclusion of the Battle of Grand Couronné ends the Battle of the Frontiers, with the north-east segment of the Western Front stabilising. South African troops open hostilities in German South-West Africa (modern-day Namibia), with an assault on the Ramansdrift police station.
The Greek army occupies Northern Epirus with the approval of the Allies.
At 19:00 (local time) Germany issues a 12-hour ultimatum to neutral Belgium, to allow German passage into France.
German light cruiser SMS Emden bombards Madras, the only Indian city to be attacked by the Central Powers in the War.
March 2 – Armenian genocide: Earliest recorded deportations.
April 22 – WWI: Start of Second Battle of Ypres – Germany makes its first large scale use of poison gas on the Western Front.

March 14 – WWI:
Battle of Más a Tierra: Off the coast of Chile, the British Royal Navy forces the Imperial German Navy light cruiser SMS Dresden (last survivor of the German East Asia Squadron) to scuttle. Constantinople Agreement: Britain, France and the Russian Empire agree to give Constantinople and the Bosphorus to Russia in case of victory (the treaty is later nullified by the Bolshevik Revolution).
May 29 – Teófilo Braga becomes president of Portugal.

July 14 – The McMahon–Hussein Correspondence between Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca and the British official Henry McMahon concerning the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire begins; in exchange for assistance against the Ottomans, the British offer bin Ali their recognition of an independent Arab kingdom, although clear terms are never agreed.
(December 17 Old Style) – The mystic Grigori Rasputin is murdered in Saint Petersburg.
October 20 – Black Friday : A violent and deadly storm hits Lake Erie in the United States.

October 28 – Pioneer Exhibition Game: game of Australian rules football contested at Queen's Club, West Kensington, London, by two teams of elite footballers selected from men serving in the First AIF at the time.
Ishikawajima Automobile Manufacturing, predecessor of Isuzu, a truck brand in Japan, is founded.
May 3-12 - 16 Irish rebel leaders who took part in the Easter Rising in Dublin in April are executed. Among them were Patrick Pearse, James Connolly and Thomas Clarke.
July 25 – Sir William Thomas White introduces Canada's first income tax as a "temporary" measure (lowest bracket is 4% and highest is 25%).
Pope Benedict XV promulgates the Code of Canon Law.

March 4
Jeannette Rankin of Montana becomes the first woman member of the United States House of Representatives.

November 20
WWI: Battle of Cambrai – British forces, using tanks, make early progress in an attack on German positions, but are soon beaten back. Ukraine is declared a republic.
March 30 – Hjalmar Hammarskjöld steps down as Prime Minister of Sweden; he is replaced by right-wing businessman and politician Carl Swartz.

December 14
Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse renounces the Finnish throne. Portuguese President Sidónio Pais is assassinated.
October 9 – Landgrave Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse is elected King of Finland.
Poland declares its independence from Russia.

September 26 – WWI:
The Meuse-Argonne Offensive begins, the largest and bloodiest operation of the war for the American Expeditionary Forces. The Capture of Damascus begins, with the Charge at Irbid by the 4th Cavalry Division.
August 27 – Battle of Ambos Nogales: U.S. Army forces skirmish against Mexican Carrancistas and their German advisors at Nogales, Arizona, in the only battle of WWI fought on United States soil.
April 5 – Pinsk massacre: 35 Jews are killed by the Polish Army without trial after being accused of Bolshevism.
November 10 – Abrams v. United States: The Supreme Court of the United States upholds the conviction of Abrams for inciting resistance to the war effort against Soviet Russia.
February 13 – Portugal's Monarchy of the North ends as a result of a revolt in Porto by civilians and National Republican Guard members.
February 26 – Grand Canyon National Park: An act of the United States Congress establishes most of the Grand Canyon as a United States National Park.
April 10 – Mexican Revolution leader Emiliano Zapata is ambushed and shot dead in Morelos.
April 11 – Mexican Revolution: Álvaro Obregón flees from Mexico City (during a trial intended to ruin his reputation) to Guerrero, where he joins Fortunato Maycotte.

August 14–September 12 – Main events of the Summer Olympics in Antwerp, Belgium (there have been ceremonies and outlying events since April). The Olympic symbols of five interlocking rings and the associated flag are first displayed at the games.
March 25 – Irish War of Independence: British recruits to the Royal Irish Constabulary begin to arrive in Ireland. They become known from their improvised uniforms as the "Black and Tans".

March 15–16 – Constantinople is occupied by British Empire forces, acting for the Allied Powers against the Turkish National Movement. Retrospectively, the Grand National Assembly of Turkey regards this as the dissolution of the Ottoman regime in Istanbul.
The League of Nations Covenant enters into force. On January 16, the organization holds its first council meeting, in Paris.
July 23 – 1st National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party opens in Shanghai.
July 17 – The Republic of Mirdita is proclaimed near the Albanian-Serbian border, with Yugoslav support.

June 10 – Paris declaration: Representatives of the three states of Transcaucasia and the North Caucasus (the Armenian, Azerbaijani and Georgian Socialist Soviet Republics) proclaim their independence, establishing a customs union and military alliance, not internationally recognized.
July 14 – A Massachusetts jury finds Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti guilty of first degree murder following a widely publicized trial whose verdict will spark protests around the world.
March 24 – The Women's Olympiad (the first international women's sports event) begins in Monte Carlo.
The last hunted California grizzly bear is shot.

In the United Kingdom general election forced by the Conservatives' withdrawal from the coalition government, the Conservative Party wins an overall majority. Labour for the first time becomes the main opposition party, winning more seats than the divided Liberals.
November 19 – Abdülmecid II, Crown Prince of the Ottoman Empire, is elected Caliph.
September 17 – Dutch cyclist Piet Moeskops becomes world champion sprinter.
March 16 – The Rand Rebellion, which began as a strike by white South African mine workers on 28 December and became open rebellion against the state, is suppressed.

November 1
The Finnish flag carrier airline Finnair is started, as Aero oy. The Victorian Police strike begins in Australia, with half of the Victoria Police force standing down over the use of labor spies.
December 21 – The Nepal–Britain Treaty is the first to define the international status of Nepal as an independent sovereign country.
May 20 – British Prime Minister Bonar Law resigns, due to ill health.
March 17 – Dobrolyot is formed as the first Soviet civil aviation service; it will become part of flag carrier Aeroflot.
August 30 – Hurricane season begins, with a tropical storm northeast of the Turks and Caicos Islands.
November 10 – The Trial of the 149 begins in Estonia, eventually resulting in the conviction of 129 communists, including several members of the Riigikogu.
The Temporary Slavery Commission is created by the League of Nations.
March 6 – İsmet İnönü forms a new government in Turkey (2nd government).

July 12 – United States occupation of the Dominican Republic (–24) comes to an end. The constitutional government headed by General Horacio Vázquez, elected in the elections held in March, is established.
Calvin Coolidge becomes the first President of the United States to deliver a radio broadcast from the White House.
May 5 – The General Election Law is passed in Japan, extending suffrage to all males aged 25 and over.
March 31 – The Bauhaus closes in Weimar and moves to a building in Dessau designed by Walter Gropius.

June 13 – American engineer Charles Francis Jenkins achieves the first synchronized transmission of pictures and sound, using 48 lines and a mechanical system in "the first public demonstration of radiovision".
March 6 – Pionerskaya Pravda, one of the oldest children's newspapers in Europe, is founded in the Soviet Union.

July 21 – English racing motorist Malcolm Campbell becomes the first man to exceed 150 mph (241 km/h) on land when at Pendine Sands in Wales he drives a Sunbeam 350HP automobile at a two-way average speed of 150.33 mph (242 km/h).
March 23 – Éamon de Valera organises the political party Fianna Fáil in Ireland.
September 11 – In Rome, Italy, Gino Lucetti throws a bomb at Benito Mussolini's car, but Mussolini is unhurt.
June 7 – Liberal politician Carl Gustaf Ekman succeeds Rickard Sandler as Prime Minister of Sweden.
March 16 – Robert H. Goddard launches the first liquid-fuel rocket, at Auburn, Massachusetts.

September 20 – The North Side Gang attempts to assassinate Al Capone, at the apex of his power at this time, spraying his headquarters in Cicero, Illinois with over a thousand rounds of machine gun fire in broad daylight, as Capone is eating there. Capone escapes harm.
July 1 – The Food, Drug, and Insecticide Administration is established as a United States federal agency.

June 29–July 1 – Commander Richard E. Byrd, Bernt Balchen, George Noville and Bert Acosta take off from Roosevelt Field, New York, in the Fokker Trimotor airplane America, and cross the Atlantic to the coast of France, having to ditch there because of bad weather; all four men survive the emergency landing.
The Holland Tunnel opens to traffic, as the first vehicular tunnel under the Hudson River, linking New Jersey with New York City.
May 20 – By the Treaty of Jeddah, the United Kingdom recognizes the sovereignty of Ibn Saud over the Kingdom of Hejaz and Nejd, the future Saudi Arabia.

June 29 – Solar eclipse of June 29, : A total eclipse of the sun takes place over Wales, northern England, southern Scotland, Norway, northern Sweden, northmost Finland, and the northmost extremes of Russia.
March 24 – Excavation work begins after the old Canaanite city of Ugarit is accidentally rediscovered.

June 9
Australian aviator Charles Kingsford Smith and his crew complete the first flight across the Pacific Ocean, from the mainland United States to Australia, in the Fokker F.VII aircraft Southern Cross. Having left Oakland, California on May 31, they reach Brisbane via Honolulu and Fiji.
January 17 – The OGPU arrests Leon Trotsky in Moscow; he assumes a status of passive resistance and is exiled with his family.
June 4 – Huanggutun incident: Zhang Zuolin, a warlord, is killed by Japanese agents in China.
November 6 – United States presidential election: Republican Herbert Hoover wins by a wide margin, over Democratic New York Governor Al Smith.
July 29 – the French prime minister Raymond Poincaré resigns, and is succeeded by Aristide Briand.
December 27 – Soviet General Secretary Joseph Stalin orders the "liquidation of the kulaks as a class".
December – New York toy salesman Edwin S. Lowe popularizes Bingo after coming across the game of "Beano" in Atlanta, Georgia.
February 9 – "Litvinov's Pact" is signed in Moscow by the Soviet Union, Poland, Estonia, Romania and Latvia, who agree not to use force to settle disputes between themselves.
An annular solar eclipse is seen over the Atlantic Ocean and Africa.
International Unemployment Day is observed in countries throughout the world.
October 24 – Brazilian Revolution of : Getúlio Vargas overthrows Washington Luís.
July 29 – British airship R100 sets out for a successful 78-hour passage to Canada.

March 12 – Mahatma Gandhi sets off on a 200-mile march towards the sea with 78 followers to protest against the British monopoly on salt in India; more will join them during the Salt March that ends on April 5.
The Turkestan–Siberia Railway is completed.
March 31 – An earthquake destroys Managua, Nicaragua, killing 2,000 people.
March 5 – The British viceroy of India and Mohandas Gandhi sign the Gandhi–Irwin Pact.

June 19
In an attempt to stop the banking crisis in Central Europe from causing a worldwide financial meltdown, U.S. President Herbert Hoover issues the Hoover Moratorium.

June–November – China flood: the Yangtze and Huai Rivers flood in a populous region, leaving an estimated 422,000 dead (150,000 drowned) with many more dying of consequential starvation and disease in the aftermath.
January 4 – German pilot Elly Beinhorn begins her flight to Africa.
December 12 – Japan and the Soviet Union reform their diplomatic connections.
August – A farmers' revolt begins in the Midwestern United States.

August 5 – Hitler meets with Schleicher and reneges on the "gentlemen's agreement", demanding that he be appointed Chancellor. Schleicher agrees to support Hitler as Chancellor provided that he can remain minister of defense.
C. June – The Republican Citizens Committee Against National Prohibition is established for the repeal of Prohibition in the United States.
May 20–21 – Amelia Earhart flies from the United States to County Londonderry, Northern Ireland in 14 hours 54 minutes.
December 5 – The Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, repealing Prohibition in the United States, making production and sale of alcohol legal in the U.S.
April 11 – Aviator Bill Lancaster takes off from Lympne in England, in an attempt to make a speed record to the Cape of Good Hope, but vanishes (his body is not found in the Sahara Desert until ).

April 3
An anti-monarchist rebellion occurs in Siam. The first flight over Mount Everest is made by the British Houston-Mount Everest Flight Expedition, led by the Marquis of Clydesdale, and funded by Lucy, Lady Houston.
November 19 – Second Spanish Republic: General elections result in a victory by the right-wing parties.
The Four-Power Pact is signed by Britain, France, Germany and Italy.
August 19 – German referendum: In a referendum, 90% of the German population approves of Hitler's assumption of presidential powers, as Führer and Reichskanzler.
March 12 – Prime Minister Konstantin Päts stages a self-coup by declaring a state of emergency in Estonia, with the approval of the parliament, beginning the country's Era of Silence.
July 1 – The Hays Code begins to be strictly enforced in the Hollywood film industry, lasting until.
June 18 – The Indian Reorganization Act is enacted.
August 8 – The Wehrmacht swears a personal oath of loyalty to Adolf Hitler.
December 17 – The Douglas DST, prototype of the Douglas DC-3 airliner, first flies in the United States. More than 16,000 of the model will eventually be produced.
January 13 – A plebiscite in the Territory of the Saar Basin shows that 90.3% of those voting wish to join Germany.
In Germany, Regina Jonas becomes the first woman ever to receive semikhah as a rabbi within Judaism. She will be killed in Auschwitz concentration camp in and the next such ordination will be in.
June 18 – Anglo-German Naval Agreement: Britain agrees to a German navy equal to 35% of her own naval tonnage.
August 13 – An estimated 250 people are killed when a dam bursts near Ovada, Italy.
August 14 – Summer Olympics: The Junior Varsity Rowing Crew from the University of Washington surprises the world listening on radio when they come from behind to win Olympic Gold.

Edward VIII abdication crisis: The British Parliament passes His Majesty's Declaration of Abdication Act on behalf of the U.K., Australia, New Zealand and South Africa. The King performs his last act as sovereign by giving Royal Assent to the Act, and his brother Prince Albert, Duke of York, becomes King, reigning as King George VI.
Nestlé introduce the white chocolate Milkybar (called Galak in Continental Europe and elsewhere).
May 9 – Speaking in Rome, Benito Mussolini announces the foundation of the empire, as Italian East Africa is formed from the Italian territories of Eritrea, Ethiopia and Italian Somaliland.
June 26 – Focke-Wulf Fw 61, the first fully controllable helicopter, makes its maiden flight.
Roberto Ortiz is elected president of Argentina.
July 9 – Fox vault fire: The silent film archives of Fox Film Corporation are destroyed.

December 12
USS Panay incident: Japanese bombers sink the American gunboat USS Panay on the Yangtze in China; the United States accepts the Japanese statement that this was unintentional. Mae West makes a risqué guest appearance on NBC's Chase and Sanborn Hour, which eventually results in her being banned from radio.
February 8–27 – Spanish Civil War – Battle of Jarama: Nationalist and Republican troops fight to a stalemate.
The Allen Organ Company, builder of church, home and theatre organs, is founded in Macungie, Pennsylvania.

September 28 – As his self-imposed October 1 deadline for occupation of the Sudetenland approaches, Adolf Hitler invites Italian Duce Benito Mussolini, French Premier Edourd Deladier and British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to one last conference in Munich. The Czechs themselves are not invited.
January 1 – State-owned railway networks are created by merger, in France and the Netherlands (Nederlandse Spoorwegen – NS).

April 10
Édouard Daladier becomes prime minister of France. He appoints as Foreign Minister a leading advocate of the policy of appeasement, Georges Bonnet, effectively negating Blum's reassurances of March 14.
Celâl Bayar forms the new government of Turkey (10th government; Celal Bayar had served twice as a prime minister).
October 4 – The Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War begin withdrawing their foreign volunteers from combat, as agreed on July 5.
June 14 – Tientsin Incident: The Japanese blockade the British concession in Tianjin, China, beginning a crisis which almost causes an Anglo-Japanese war in the summer of.

September 4 – WWII:
The first bombing of Wilhelmshaven in World War II is carried out, by the British Royal Air Force. The Defense of Katowice by irregular Polish militia fails and the city is secured by German Wehrmacht forces who carry out the Katowice massacre.

September 17 – WWII:
The Soviet Union invades Poland, and then occupies eastern Polish territories. Royal Navy aircraft carrier HMS Courageous is torpedoed and sunk by German submarine U-29 in the Western Approaches with the loss of 519 crew (the first British warship loss of the war).
September 13–14 – WWII: Zambrów massacre – German Wehrmacht soldiers shoot more than 200 Polish prisoners of war.
May 14 – Lina Medina, a 5-year-old Peruvian girl, gives birth to a baby boy, becoming the youngest confirmed mother in medical history.
November 9 – Joaquín Rodrigo's Concierto de Aranjuez for classical guitar and orchestra premieres in Barcelona, Spain.
The 2600th Anniversary Celebrations of the Japanese Empire.
The Norwegian Army surrenders to German forces.
Plutonium is first synthesized in the laboratory, by a team led by Glenn T. Seaborg and Edwin McMillan, at the University of California, Berkeley.
May 13–14 – Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands and her government are evacuated to London, using the British destroyer HMS Hereward.
WWII: The National Liberation Front (the main Greek Resistance movement) is established, and Georgios Siantos is appointed its first acting leader.
July 3 – WWII: Joseph Stalin, in his first address since the German invasion, calls upon the Soviet people to carry out a "scorched earth" policy of resistance to the bitter end.
The Holocaust: Units of the Wehrmacht and the Einsatzgruppen (as part of Operation Barbarossa) start killing Jewish children, signalling the start of the Jewish Genocide.
April 18 – WWII: Greek Prime Minister Alexandros Koryzis commits suicide as German troops approach Athens.
May 29 – The Disney animators' strike begins, due to lack of recognition by Walt Disney of his animators' inequities of pay and privileges.
A riot involving infantrymen, military police, and local law enforcement officers occurs in Phoenix, Arizona, United States, leading to three deaths.

June 1
WWII: Mexico declares war on Germany, Italy and Japan. The Grand Coulee Dam is finished on the Columbia River in the United States.

January 11 – WWII:
Dutch East Indies campaign: Japan declares war on the Netherlands and the Dutch East Indies. Japanese forces invade Borneo and Celebes.

August 11 – Hedy Lamarr's and her friend George Antheil's frequency-hopping system for radio-controlled torpedoes is granted a patent under U.S. patent 2,292,387. In (at the time of the Cuban missile crisis), an updated version of their design will at last appear on Navy ships.

June 18 – WWII: The SS surrounds the church in Prague where Jan Kubiš and Jozef Gabčík, the assassins of Reinhard Heydrich, are hiding. Kubiš is fatally wounded in the ensuing shootout, and Gabčík commits suicide to avoid capture.

April 21 – WWII:
Aberdeen, Scotland, experiences its worst bombing, with 125 people killed. The first German Tiger I tank is captured in North Africa by British forces.

Operation Case Black: Axis forces begin a joint offensive, with the aim of destroying the Yugoslav Partisans, in south-eastern Bosnia. During the offensive, some 7,500 partisans are killed or wounded.
September 23 – WWII: The Italian Social Republic ("Republic of Salò") is founded in northern Italy as a puppet state of Nazi Germany.
March – Exiled French aviator Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's self-illustrated children's novella, The Little Prince, is published in New York City, the all-time best-selling book originating in French.
January 16 – Iraq declares war on the Axis powers.
Landing at Saidor: 13,000 US and Australian troops land on Papua New Guinea in an attempt to cut off a Japanese retreat.
December 1 – Edward Stettinius, Jr. becomes the last United States Secretary of State of the Roosevelt administration, filling the seat left by Cordell Hull.

Deportation of the Chechens and Ingush ("Operation Lentil"): Forced deportation of Chechens and Ingush people from North Caucasus to Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in Central Asia by the Soviet authorities begins.

August 25 – WWII:
German surrender of Paris:The Allies enter Paris in force and General Dietrich von Choltitz surrenders the city to them, in defiance of Hitler's orders to destroy it. This successfully completes Operation Overlord.

July 4 – WWII: Operation Windsor: Canadian forces of the 3rd Canadian Infantry Division attack Carpiquet airfield defended by German troops of the 12th SS Panzer Division Hitlerjugend of Panzergruppe West.

April 28
The bodies of Benito Mussolini, his mistress, Clara Petacci, and other followers are hung by their heels at a gas station in the public square of Milan, Piazzale Loreto, following their execution by Italian partisans after an attempt to flee the country. The Canadian First Army captures Emden and Wilhelmshaven.

Winston Churchill resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, after his Conservative Party is soundly defeated by the Labour Party in the general election. Clement Attlee becomes the new prime minister.
The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is declared (this day is celebrated as Republic Day until the 1990s). Marshal Tito is named president.
WWII: The Red Army almost destroys the German 4th Army, in the Heiligenbeil Pocket in East Prussia.

December 2
General Eurico Gaspar Dutra is elected president of Brazil. French banks (Bank of France, BNCI, CNEP, Crédit Lyonnais, and Société Générale) are nationalized.

October 16
The remaining ten Nazi war criminals sentenced to death at the Nuremberg trials are executed by hanging, in a gymnasium in the Palace of Justice, Nuremberg. The United Nations' first meeting in Long Island is held.
Trygve Lie of Norway is selected as the first United Nations Secretary-General.
June 13 – Umberto II of Italy leaves the country and goes into exile in Portugal; Alcide De Gasperi becomes head of state.
General Douglas MacArthur establishes the International Military Tribunal for the Far East in Tokyo, to try Japanese war criminals.
In the last mass lynching in the United States, a mob of white men shoot and kill two African-American couples, near Moore's Ford Bridge in Georgia.
The lowest air temperature in North America (−63 degrees Celsius) was recorded in Snag, in the Yukon Territory.
January 10 – The United Nations adopts a resolution to take control of the free city of Trieste.
January 15 – Elizabeth Short, an aspiring actress nicknamed the "Black Dahlia", is found brutally murdered in a vacant lot in Los Angeles; the mysterious case is never solved.

December 6
Arturo Toscanini conducts a concert performance of the first half of Giuseppe Verdi's opera Otello, for a broadcast on NBC Radio in the United States. The second half of the opera is broadcast a week later.
March 29 – A rebellion against French rule erupts in Madagascar.

Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 is played on television in its entirety for the first time, in a series of concerts featuring Arturo Toscanini conducting the NBC Symphony Orchestra in the United States. The chorus is conducted by Robert Shaw.
September 5 – Robert Schuman becomes Prime Minister of France.
The Berlin Airlift begins.
Liberal politician Jorge Eliécer Gaitán's assassination provokes a violent riot in Bogotá (the Bogotazo) and a further 10 years of violence (La Violencia) across Colombia.

June 21
The Deutsche Mark becomes the official currency of the future Federal Republic of Germany. The Manchester Baby in England becomes the first stored-program computer to successfully execute a program.
The Queen Charlotte Islands earthquake is Canada's largest earthquake since the 1700 Cascadia earthquake.
April 4 – The North Atlantic Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C., creating the NATO defense alliance.

Air France Lockheed Constellation crash: An Air France flight from Paris to New York crashes in the Azores on São Miguel Island, killing all aboard. Among the victims are violinist Ginette Neveu, and French boxer Marcel Cerdan.
Notorious World War II veteran Edwin Alonzo Boyd commits his first career bank robbery, in Toronto.
Siam officially changes its French name to "Thaïlande" (English name to "Thailand"), having officially changed its Thai name to "Prated Thai" since.

February 8
The Stasi is founded in East Germany, and acts as a secret police until. A payment is first made by Diners Club card, in New York, United States (the first use of a charge card).
October 5 – The Indonesian government quells riots in the Moluccas.
January 13 – Finland forms diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.
Britain formally recognises Israel.

March 12
A plane carrying returning rugby fans from Ireland to Wales crashes near Llandow, with the loss of 80 lives. Royal question: Belgian monarchy referendum – In Belgium, a referendum on the monarchy shows 57.7% support the return of King Leopold III from exile to resume exercise of his constitutional powers, 42.3% against.
On television, the situation comedy I Love Lucy airs its first episode on CBS in the U.S.
A formal peace agreement between Canada and Germany is signed.
February 1–2 – The Nepalese revolution leads to agreement for a democratic constitution.
August 31 – The first Volkswagen Type 1 rolls off the production line in Uitenhage, South Africa.
April 24 – Sakuragichō train fire: in Yokohama, Japan, a fire on a train kills more than 100.
United States presidential election: Republican General Dwight D. Eisenhower defeats Democratic Governor of Illinois Adlai Stevenson (correctly predicted by the UNIVAC computer).
October 19 – Alain Bombard begins to sail from the Canary Islands to Barbados in 65 days; he reaches them December 23.
August 27 – Reparation negotiations between West Germany and Israel end in Luxembourg: Germany will pay 3 billion Deutsche Marks.
West Ice accidents: During a severe storm in the West Ice, east of Greenland, 78 seal hunters on 5 Norwegian seal hunting vessels vanish without a trace.
May 13 – Pandit Nehru forms his first government in India.
October 22 – Laos becomes independent from France.
May 25 – Nuclear testing: At the Nevada Test Site, the United States conducts its only nuclear artillery test: Upshot-Knothole Grable.
The Douglas D-558-2 Skyrocket, piloted by Scott Crossfield, becomes the first manned aircraft to reach Mach 2.
November 29 – First Indochina War: Battle of Dien Bien Phu – French paratroopers consolidate their position at Điện Biên Phủ.
July 17 – The greatest recorded loss of United States midshipmen in a single event results from an aircraft crash near NAS Whiting Field.
November 21 – People's Action Party, an eventual dominative political party in Singapore, was established.

September 14
The Soviet Union carries out the Totskoye nuclear exercise. English composer Benjamin Britten's chamber opera version of The Turn of the Screw receives its world premiere, at the Teatro La Fenice in Venice, Italy.
March 23 – In Vietnam, the Viet Minh capture the main airstrip of Dien Bien Phu. The remaining French Army units there are partially isolated.
August 24 – Brazilian president Getúlio Vargas commits suicide, after being accused of involvement in a conspiracy to murder his chief political opponent, Carlos Lacerda.
The first electric drip brew coffeemaker is patented in Germany and named the Wigomat after its inventor Gottlob Widmann.
May 25 – Joe Brown and George Band are the first to climb Kangchenjunga in the Himalayas, as part of the British Kangchenjunga expedition led by Charles Evans.
December 22 – American cytogeneticist Joe Hin Tjio discovers the correct number of human chromosomes, forty-six.
November 15 – The Democratic Party of Japan and Japan Liberal Party merge to form the Japan Liberal Democratic Party, beginning the " System".
September 6 – Istanbul pogrom: Istanbul's Greek minority is the target of a government-sponsored pogrom.
Winston Churchill resigns as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, due to ill-health, at the age of 80.
March 19 – At age 48, Dutch boxer Bep van Klaveren contests his last match in Rotterdam.
November 23 – The Suez Crisis causes petrol rationing in Britain.
September 21 – Nicaraguan dictator Anastasio Somoza García is assassinated.
A United States Navy team becomes the third group to reach the South Pole (arriving by air), and commences construction of the first permanent Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station.

September 13
The hard disk drive is invented by an IBM team, led by Reynold B. Johnson.
December 20 – The Boeing 707 airliner flies for the first time.
Heavy rains and mudslides at Isahaya, western Kyūshū, Japan, kill 992.
March 8 – Egypt re-opens the Suez Canal.
September 29 – The Kyshtym disaster occurs at the Mayak nuclear reprocessing plant in Russia.

The first nuclear-powered submarine, USS Nautilus, logs its 60,000th nautical mile, matching the endurance of the fictional Nautilus described in Jules Verne's novel Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Seas. It is decommissioned on March 3,.
September 1 – The first Cod War begins between the United Kingdom and Iceland.

March 2 – A British Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition team, led by Sir Vivian Fuchs, completes the first overland crossing of the Antarctic, using snowcat caterpillar tractors and dogsled teams, in 99 days, via the South Pole.

April 28 – A bomber flown by a U.S. Central Intelligence Agency operative in support of Indonesian Permesta rebels bombs the harbor at Balikpapan, Borneo, Indonesia, hitting an Indonesian naval corvette and two British oil tankers.
Sputnik 1 (launched on October 4, ) falls towards Earth from its orbit and burns up.
November 10 – Harry Winston donates the Hope Diamond to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.
March 19 – The other two southern islands of the Maldives, Huvadhu Atoll and Fuvahmulah, join Addu Atoll in forming the United Suvadive Republic (abolished September ).

June 30 – Okinawa F-100 crash: Twenty-one students are killed and more than a hundred injured when a U.S. Air Force North American F-100 Super Sabre jet crashes into Miamori Elementary School on the Japanese island of Okinawa.
January 21 – The European Court of Human Rights is established.
The Hebgen Lake earthquake in southwest Montana kills 28.
May 21 – Gypsy: A Musical Fable, starring Ethel Merman in her last new musical, opens on Broadway and runs for 702 performances.
A Soviet satellite containing live animals (dogs Pcholka and Mushka) and plants is launched into orbit. Due to a malfunction, it burns up during re-entry.

January 21
Coalbrook mining disaster: A coal mine collapses at Holly Country, South Africa, killing 435 miners. Avianca Flight 671 crashes and burns upon landing at Montego Bay, Jamaica killing 37, the worst air disaster in Jamaica's history and the first for Avianca.
April 4 – At the 32nd Academy Awards Ceremony, Ben-Hur wins a record 11 Oscars, including Best Picture.
September 6 – Martin and Mitchell defection: William Hamilton Martin and Bernon F. Mitchell, two American cryptologists, announce their defection to the Soviet Union at a press conference in Moscow.

January 19 – A revised version of the Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and Japan ("U.S.-Japan Security Treaty" or "Anpo "), which allows U.S. troops to be based on Japanese soil, is signed in Washington, D.C. by Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi and President Dwight D. Eisenhower.
August 7 – Vostok 2 lands in the Soviet Union.
December 23 – Luxembourg's national holiday, the Grand Duke's Official Birthday, is set on June 23 by Grand Ducal decree.
June 12 – A patent for the body electrode invented by Richard M. Berman and Bernard Schwartz is applied for.
May 14 – Civil rights movement: A Freedom Riders bus is fire-bombed near Anniston, Alabama, and the civil rights protestors are beaten by an angry mob of Ku Klux Klan members.
Sierra Leone becomes independent from the United Kingdom.
December 24 – Cuba releases the last 1,113 participants in the Bay of Pigs Invasion to the U.S., in exchange for food worth $53 million.

The first black student, James Meredith, registers at the University of Mississippi, escorted by Federal Marshals to protect him from official obstruction and violent segregationalist protest, the "Ole Miss riot of ".

July 31
Algeria proclaims independence; Ahmed Ben Bella is the first President. A crowd assaults a rally of Sir Oswald Mosley's right-wing Union Movement in London.
August 11 – King Kong vs. Godzilla is released in Japan, becoming the first Godzilla and King Kong film in colour.
November 25 – The Bavarian state election is held.
September 15 – American civil rights movement: The 16th Street Baptist Church bombing, in Birmingham, Alabama, kills 4 and injures 22.
November 8 – Finnair aircraft OH-LCA crashes before landing at Mariehamn Airport on Åland.
The cancellation of Mercury-Atlas 10 effectively ends the United States' crewed spaceflight Project Mercury.

November 24
Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of John F. Kennedy, is shot dead by Jack Ruby in Dallas, an event seen on live national television.
The New York Commodity Exchange begins trading silver futures contracts.
May 29 – Having deposed them in a January coup, South Vietnamese leader Nguyen Khanh has rival Generals Tran Van Don and Le Van Kim convicted of "lax morality".

July 20
Vietnam War: Viet Cong forces attack a provincial capital, killing 11 South Vietnamese military personnel and 40 civilians (30 of which are children). The National Movement of the Revolution is established in the Republic of the Congo, becoming the country's sole legal political party.

The Danish football club Brøndby IF is founded as a merger between the two local clubs Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening and Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening. The club wins the national championship Danish Superliga 10 times, and the Danish Cups six times, after joining the Danish top-flight football league in.
The Bolivian government of President Víctor Paz Estenssoro is overthrown by a military rebellion led by General Alfredo Ovando Candía, commander-in-chief of the armed forces.

August 27 – Walt Disney's Mary Poppins has its world premiere in Los Angeles. It will go on to become Disney's biggest moneymaker, and winner of 5 Academy Awards, including a Best Actress for Julie Andrews.
November 15 – U.S. racer Craig Breedlove sets a new land speed record of 600.601 mph (966.574 km/h).
In Rhodesia (modern-day Zimbabwe), the white-minority government of Ian Smith unilaterally declares de facto independence ('UDI').
Suat Hayri Ürgüplü forms the new government of Turkey (29th government).
Gemini 6 and Gemini 7 perform the first controlled rendezvous in Earth orbit.
The Indo-Pakistani War of begins.
September 19 – Indonesian military commander (later President) Suharto announces the resumption of Indonesian participation in the United Nations.

Topeka tornado: Topeka, Kansas, is devastated by a tornado that registers as an "F5" on the Fujita scale, the first to exceed US$100 million in damages. Sixteen people are killed, hundreds more injured and thousands of homes damaged or destroyed, and the campus of Washburn University suffers catastrophic damage.
November 10 – Seán Lemass retires as Taoiseach of the Republic of Ireland, to be replaced in the role by fellow Fianna Fáil member Jack Lynch.
The British government promises the U.S. that British troops in Malaysia will stay until more peaceful conditions occur in the region.

March 20 – Football's FIFA World Cup Trophy is stolen while on exhibition in London; it is found seven days later by a mongrel dog named "Pickles" and his owner David Corbett, wrapped in newspaper in a south London garden.
The United States, Soviet Union and United Kingdom sign the Outer Space Treaty (ratified by USSR May 19; comes into force October 10), prohibiting weapons of mass destruction from space.
June 25 – 400 million viewers watch Our World, the first live, international, satellite television production. It features the live debut of The Beatles' song "All You Need Is Love".
February 10 – The Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution (presidential succession and disability) is ratified.
June 18 – Eighteen British soldiers are killed in the Aden police mutiny.

October 12
Vietnam War: U.S. Secretary of State Dean Rusk states during a news conference that, because of North Vietnam's opposition, proposals by the U.S.

April 10 – The ferry TEV Wahine strikes a reef at the mouth of Wellington Harbour, New Zealand, with the loss of 53 lives, in Cyclone Giselle, which has created the windiest conditions ever recorded in New Zealand.

April 4
Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.: Martin Luther King Jr. is shot dead at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee by James Earl Ray. King-assassination riots erupt in major American cities, lasting for several days afterwards.

February 1
Vietnam War: Execution of Nguyễn Văn Lém – A Viet Cong officer is summarily executed by Nguyễn Ngọc Loan, a South Vietnamese National Police Chief. The event is photographed by Eddie Adams.
April 7 – British racing driver Jim Clark is killed in a Formula 2 race at Hockenheim.
June 2 – Student demonstrations in Yugoslavia start in Belgrade.
January 16 – First successful docking of two crewed spacecraft in orbit and the first transfer of crew from one space vehicle to another (by a space walk) between Soviet craft Soyuz 5 and Soyuz 4.
Apollo program: Apollo 10 returns to Earth, after a successful 8-day test of all the components needed for the upcoming first crewed Moon landing.
John Lennon and Yoko Ono are married at Gibraltar, and proceed to their honeymoon "Bed-in" for peace in Amsterdam.

December 6 – Meredith Hunter is stabbed to death by Hells Angels at the Altamont Free Concert, an event which came to be viewed as the end of the hippie era and the de facto conclusion of late-1960s American youth culture.
May 17 – Venera program: Soviet space probe Venera 6 begins to descend into Venus's atmosphere, sending back atmospheric data before being crushed by pressure.

Gary Gabelich drives the rocket-powered Blue Flame (part fuelled by LNG) to an official land speed record of 622.407 mph (1,001.667 km/h) on the dry lake bed of the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah. The record, the first above 1,000 km/h, stands for nearly 13 years.
December 25 – ETA releases Eugen Beihl in Spain.

November 22 – Guinean president Ahmed Sékou Touré accuses Portugal of an attack when hundreds of mercenaries land near the capital Conakry. The Guinean army repels the landing attempts over the next three days.
October 12 – Vietnam War: U.S. President Richard Nixon announces that the United States will withdraw 40,000 more troops before Christmas.
February 1 – The Benavídez rail disaster near Buenos Aires, Argentina (a rear-end collision) kills 236.
Libya, Syria and Egypt sign an agreement to form a confederation.
June 14 – Norway begins oil production in the North Sea.
April 8 – A right-wing coup attempt is exposed in Laos.
